content.raw:
My understanding is that pkg-config syntax allows a version number to be specified or omitted after the `>=` operator. If a number is not detected, it ignores the `>=` and treats the next token as the next dependency. So, it should be interpreted as if the `>=` is not there.

What is the error message that you are seeing and what operating system are you using?
content.html:
My understanding is that pkg-config syntax allows a version number to be specified or omitted after the >= operator. If a number is not detected, it ignores the >= and treats the next token as the next dependency. So, it should be interpreted as if the >= is not there.

What is the error message that you are seeing and what operating system are you using?

content.raw:
Apart from the fact that I don't see how one could interpret `libcurl >=` as a valid version comparison, it seems that it's also unexpected per the pkg-config specification.

I can't find a specification for `.pc` on freedesktop.org, but the pkg-config website refers to https://people.freedesktop.org/~dbn/pkg-config-guide.html, which says:

*The Version field is a bit trickier to ensure that it is usable by consumers of the data. pkg-config uses the algorithm from RPM for version comparisons. This works best with a dotted decimal number such as 1.2.3 since letters can cause unexpected results. The number should be monotonically increasing and be as specific as possible in describing the library. Usually it's sufficient to use the package's version number here since it's easy for consumers to track.*

Somebody in the Gentoo project wrote a more formal description, and for [the version specification](https://dev.gentoo.org/~mgorny/pkg-config-spec.html#version-comparison) claims that RPM uses a "segmented alphanumeric" algorithm. As I understand it, `jsoncpp ` would be a valid version from this algorithm point of view.

And indeeed, it's what it is:

~~~
$ cat bla.pc
Name: Ignition fuel_tools
Description:
Version: 1.0.0
Requires.private: libcurl >=  jsoncpp yaml-0.1

$ PKG_CONFIG_PATH=$PWD pkg-config --print-requires-private bla
libcurl >= jsoncpp
yaml-0.1
~~~
content.html:
Apart from the fact that I don't see how one could interpret libcurl >= as a valid version comparison, it seems that it's also unexpected per the pkg-config specification.

I can't find a specification for .pc on freedesktop.org, but the pkg-config website refers to https://people.freedesktop.org/~dbn/pkg-config-guide.html, which says:

The Version field is a bit trickier to ensure that it is usable by consumers of the data. pkg-config uses the algorithm from RPM for version comparisons. This works best with a dotted decimal number such as 1.2.3 since letters can cause unexpected results. The number should be monotonically increasing and be as specific as possible in describing the library. Usually it's sufficient to use the package's version number here since it's easy for consumers to track.

Somebody in the Gentoo project wrote a more formal description, and for the version specification claims that RPM uses a "segmented alphanumeric" algorithm. As I understand it, jsoncpp would be a valid version from this algorithm point of view.

And indeeed, it's what it is:

$ cat bla.pc
Name: Ignition fuel_tools
Description:
Version: 1.0.0
Requires.private: libcurl >=  jsoncpp yaml-0.1

$ PKG_CONFIG_PATH=$PWD pkg-config --print-requires-private bla
libcurl >= jsoncpp
yaml-0.1

content.raw: I stand corrected. I hadn't tried the `--print-requires-private` flag, but I see the same thing.
content.html: I stand corrected. I hadn't tried the --print-requires-private flag, but I see the same thing.
